Award.AbstractNarration: The goal of this project is the development of a method that enables the isolation of a population of mutant embryos that does not rely on identification by visible defect. Development is a universal process where a fertilized egg matures into a fully formed organism. In the quest to understand organismal development, it has been the focus of intensive scientific investigation for more than a century. Despite its long history of rigorous study the molecular mechanisms that drive the developmental program are still poorly understood. The study of gene mutation has thus far been one of the best tools to reveal molecular details of the developmental program. However, this approach is limited by the fact that mutant organisms are identified by visible identification of defects caused by the mutation, which are generally apparent well after the underlying molecular causes take place. Although modern technologies exist to examine the molecular changes that occur prior to visible defects, they require isolation of a large population of purely mutant organisms well before defects are apparent. Using Drosophila (fruit fly) genetic techniques, this laboratory has developed a method for generating males and females that produce only mutant sperm and eggs and therefore will create a population of purely mutant embryos that can be molecularly analyzed well before defects are visible. The focus of this project is to develop further this method so it can be broadly used to study the majority of genes in Drosophila and make it available as a general tool for all Drosophila researchers. Since many of the processes that govern organismal development are similar across species information generated using this technique in Drosophila are broadly applicable to the molecular mechanisms that drive development in other organisms, such as humans. This study will also enhance science education and promote the development of future researchers, as graduate and undergraduate researchers will be actively engaged in this project.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project was to develop a method in fruit flies to generate both males and females in which their sperm and eggs, respectively, carry a defined mutation. These flies can then be crossed together to yield all offspring that are fully mutant for the gene in question. Our work on this project has enabled us to optimize this method and generated or are in the process of generating all of the stocks that are needed for the fly community to use this method to make mutant offspring for the majority of the fruit fly genome. Previously, a similar technique has only been possible in females, but not males. Hence, this technique is a major innovation in the field, as it allows for the isolation a 100% mutant population of embryos that otherwise would not be possible. Development of this method has implications for a number of broad based proteomic and genetic screening approaches. It will enable the assessment of the paternal genome/proteome during development, permit the analysis of the interaction between two genes and provides a framework for the characterization of proteins obtained from a mutant context.

 

During the course of this work we also examined the function of two genes (alg 9 and alg10) involved in a pathway required for modifying proteins with sugars during development of the fruit fly eye. These sugar modified proteins are destined for localization outside of the cell. A group of human diseases, congenital disorders of glycosylation (CDG), arise from mutations in the genes involved in various steps of this pathway. While CDGs display pleotrophic phenotypes, many arise from neuronal defects. These modifications are known to be essential for multiple vital cellular functions including cell-cell recognition, protein trafficking and proper protein folding. We found alg 9 and alg10 cause improper cellular localization of several proteins targeted for sugar modification. Absence of sugar addition causes these proteins (chaoptin and neuoglian) to be trapped within the cell in the developing fly eye (Figure 1). Retention of these unmodified proteins results in neuronal cell death during eye development (Figure 2) preventing proper development of the adult fruit fly eye resulting in fewer neurons than normal eyes (Figure 3). The mutation that is required earlier in the pathway (alg9) had a more severe phenotype (Figures 1, 2 and 3). Cell death occurs after cells become neurons, which together suggests that neuronal cell death is due to the build up of unmodified proteins over time (Figure 2). We also found adding Alg10 protein during eye development to an alg10 mutant background restores a normal phenotype (Figures 1 and 3). These results indicate that CDG patients may develop normal neurons, but experience neuronal deficits due to intracellular accumulation of unmodified proteins leading to cell death. Further, markers of intracellular stress and accumulated unfolded protein should be examined in the future to better understand the role of this pathway in CDG.
